com.stormpath.sdk.application

Interface Application

  • All Superinterfaces:
    AccountLinker, AccountStoreHolder<Application>, Auditable, Deletable, Extendable, Resource, Saveable

    public interface Application
extends AccountStoreHolder<Application>, Resource, Saveable, Deletable, Extendable, Auditable, AccountLinker
    An Application instance represents a Stormpath registered application.
    Since:
    0.1

      • getAccounts

        AccountList getAccounts()
        Returns a paginated list of all accounts that may login to the application.

        Tip: Instead of iterating over all accounts, it might be more convenient (and practical) to execute a search for one or more accounts using the getAccounts(com.stormpath.sdk.account.AccountCriteria) or getAccounts(java.util.Map) methods instead of this one.

        Returns:
        a paginated list of all accounts that may login to the application.
        See Also:
        getAccounts(com.stormpath.sdk.account.AccountCriteria), getAccounts(java.util.Map)

      • getAccounts

        AccountList getAccounts(Map<String,Object> queryParams)
        Returns a paginated list of the accounts that may login to the application that also match the specified query criteria.

        Each queryParams key/value pair will be converted to String name to String value pairs and appended to the resource URL as query parameters, for example: 

         .../applications/applicationId/accounts?param1=value1¶m2=value2&...
        Parameters:
        queryParams - the query parameters to use when performing a request to the collection.
        Returns:
        a paginated list of the application's accounts that match the specified query criteria.
        Since:
        0.8

      • getAccounts

        AccountList getAccounts(AccountCriteria criteria)
        Returns a paginated list of the accounts that may login to the application that also match the specified query criteria. The Accounts utility class is available to help construct the criteria DSL. For example: 
         application.getAccounts(Accounts
     .where(Accounts.surname().containsIgnoreCase("Smith"))
     .and(Accounts.givenName().eqIgnoreCase("John"))
     .orderBySurname().descending()
     .withGroups(10, 10)
     .offsetBy(20)
     .limitTo(25));
        or, if using static imports: 
         import static com.stormpath.sdk.account.Accounts.*;

 ...

 application.getAccounts(where(
     surname().containsIgnoreCase("Smith"))
     .and(givenName().eqIgnoreCase("John"))
     .orderBySurname().descending()
     .withGroups(10, 10)
     .offsetBy(20)
     .limitTo(25));
        Parameters:
        criteria - the criteria to use when performing a request to the collection.
        Returns:
        a paginated list of the application's accounts that match the specified query criteria.
        Since:
        0.8

      • createAccount

        Account createAccount(Account account)
               throws ResourceException
        Creates a new Account that may login to this application.

        This is mostly a convenience method; it delegates creation to the Application's designated defaultAccountStore, and functions as follows:

        • If the defaultAccountStore is a Directory: the account is created in the Directory and returned.
        • If the defaultAccountStore is a Group: the account is created in the Group's Directory, assigned to the Group, and then returned.

        Parameters:
        account - the account to create/persist
        Returns:
        a new Account that may login to this application.
        Throws:
        ResourceException - if the Application does not have a designated defaultAccountStore or if the designated defaultAccountStore does not allow new accounts to be created.
        Since:
        0.9

      • createAccount

        Account createAccount(CreateAccountRequest request)
               throws ResourceException
        Creates a new Account that may login to this application according to the request criteria.

        This is mostly a convenience method; it delegates creation to the Application's designated defaultAccountStore, and functions as follows:

        • If the defaultAccountStore is a Directory: the account is created in the Directory and returned.
        • If the defaultAccountStore is a Group: the account is created in the Group's Directory, assigned to the Group, and then returned.

        Example

         application.createAccount(Accounts.newCreateRequestFor(account).build());

        If you would like to force disabling the backing directory's account registration workflow: 

         application.createAccount(Accounts.newCreateRequestFor(account).setRegistrationWorkflowEnabled(false).build());
        If you would like to force the execution of the registration workflow, no matter what the backing directory configuration is: 
         application.createAccount(Accounts.newCreateRequestFor(account).setRegistrationWorkflowEnabled(true).build());
        If you would like to retrieve the account's custom data in the response of the account creation. 
         application.createAccount(Accounts.newCreateRequestFor(account).withResponseOptions(Accounts.options().withCustomData()).build());

        Parameters:
        request - the account creation request
        Returns:
        a new Account that may login to this application.
        Throws:
        ResourceException - if the Application does not have a designated defaultAccountStore or if the designated defaultAccountStore does not allow new accounts to be created.
        Since:
        0.9

      • getGroups

        GroupList getGroups()
        Returns all Groups accessible to the application. It will not only return any group associated directly as an AccountStore but also every group that exists inside every directory associated as an account store.

        These groups can be used role-based access control checks, for example, 'if a user is in the admin group, allow them to delete a user'.

        If you want to control which accounts can login to an application, you control that via the application's AccountStoreMappings collection, not this method.

        Tip: Instead of iterating over all groups, it might be more convenient (and practical) to execute a search for one or more groups using the getGroups(java.util.Map) method instead of this one.

        Returns:
        all Groups accessible to the application (based on the Application's associated Account stores).
        Since:
        0.8
        See Also:
        getGroups(java.util.Map)

      • getGroups

        GroupList getGroups(Map<String,Object> queryParams)
        Returns a paginated list of the groups accessible to the application (based on the app's mapped Account stores) that also match the specified query criteria.

        Each queryParams key/value pair will be converted to String name to String value pairs and appended to the resource URL as query parameters, for example: 

         .../applications/applicationId/groups?param1=value1¶m2=value2&...
        Parameters:
        queryParams - the query parameters to use when performing a request to the collection.
        Returns:
        a paginated list of the application's groups that match the specified query criteria.
        Since:
        0.8

      • getGroups

        GroupList getGroups(GroupCriteria criteria)
        Returns a paginated list of the groups accessible to the application (based on the app's mapped Account stores) that also match the specified query criteria. The Groups utility class is available to help construct the criteria DSL. For example: 
         application.getGroups(Groups
     .where(Groups.description().containsIgnoreCase("foo"))
     .and(Groups.name().startsWithIgnoreCase("bar"))
     .orderByName().descending()
     .withAccounts(10, 10)
     .offsetBy(20)
     .limitTo(25));
        or, if using static imports: 
         import static com.stormpath.sdk.group.Groups.*;

 ...

 application.getGroups(where(
     description().containsIgnoreCase("foo"))
     .and(name().startsWithIgnoreCase("bar"))
     .orderByName().descending()
     .withAccounts(10, 10)
     .offsetBy(20)
     .limitTo(25));
        Parameters:
        criteria - the criteria to use when performing a request to the collection.
        Returns:
        a paginated list of the application's accessible groups that match the specified query criteria.
        Since:
        0.8

      • sendPasswordResetEmail

        PasswordResetToken sendPasswordResetEmail(String email)
                                   throws ResourceException
        Sends a password reset email for the specified account email address. The email will contain a password reset link that the user can click or copy into their browser address bar.

        This method merely sends the password reset email that contains the link and nothing else. You will need to handle the link requests and then reset the account's password as described in the verifyPasswordResetToken(String) JavaDoc.

        Parameters:
        email - an email address of an Account that may login to the application.
        Returns:
        the PasswordResetToken created for the password reset email sent to the specified email
        Throws:
        ResourceException - if there is no account that matches the specified email address
        See Also:
        verifyPasswordResetToken(String), resetPassword(String, String)

      • sendPasswordResetEmail

        PasswordResetToken sendPasswordResetEmail(String email,
                                          AccountStore accountStore)
                                   throws ResourceException
        Sends a password reset email to an account in the specified AccountStore matching the specified email address. If the email does not match an account in the specified AccountStore, a ResourceException will be thrown. If you are unsure of which of the application's mapped account stores might contain the account, use the more general sendPasswordResetEmail(String email) method instead.

        This method is useful as a performance enhancement if the application might be mapped to many (dozens, hundreds or thousands) of account stores. This can be common in multi-tenant applications where each mapped AccountStore represents a specific tenant or customer organization. Specifying the AccountStore in these scenarios bypasses the general email-only-based account search and performs a more-efficient direct lookup directly against the specified AccountStore. The AccountStore is usually discovered before calling this method by inspecting a submitted tenant id or subdomain, e.g. http://ACCOUNT_STORE_NAME.foo.com

        Like the sendPasswordResetEmail(String) method, this email merely sends the email that contains a link that, when clicked, will take the user to a view (web page) that allows them to specify a new password. When the new password is submitted, the verifyPasswordResetToken(String) method is expected to be called at that time.

        Parameters:
        email - an email address of an Account that may login to the application.
        accountStore - the accountStore expected to contain an account with the specified email address
        Returns:
        the PasswordResetToken created for the password reset email sent to the specified email
        Throws:
        ResourceException - if the specified AccountStore is not mapped to this application or if the email address is not in the specified Account store
        Since:
        1.0.RC3
        See Also:
        sendPasswordResetEmail(String), verifyPasswordResetToken(String), resetPassword(String, String)

      • verifyPasswordResetToken

        Account verifyPasswordResetToken(String token)
        Verifies a password reset token in a user-clicked link within an email.

        Base Link Configuration

        You need to define the Base link that will process HTTP requests when users click the link in the email as part of your Application's Workflow Configuration within the Stormpath UI Console. It must be a URL served by your application's web servers. For example: 
         https://www.myApplication.com/passwordReset

        Runtime Link Processing

        When an application user clicks on the link in the email at runtime, your web server needs to process the request and look for an spToken request parameter. You can then verify the spToken, and then finally change the Account's password.

        Usage Example:

        Browser: GET https://www.myApplication/passwordReset?spToken=someTokenValueHere

        Your code: 

         String token = httpServletRequest.getParameter("sptoken");

 Account account = application.verifyPasswordResetToken(token);

 //token has been verified - now set the new password with what the end-user submits:
 account.setPassword(user_submitted_new_password);
 account.save();
        Parameters:
        token - the verification token, usually obtained as a request parameter by your application.
        Returns:
        the Account matching the specified token.
        Since:
        0.4

      • resetPassword

        Account resetPassword(String passwordResetToken,
                      String newPassword)
        Verifies the password reset token (received in the user's email) and immediately changes the password in the same request (if the token is valid).

        NOTE: Once the token has been successfully used, it is immediately invalidated and can't be used again. If you need to change the password again, you will previously need to execute sendPasswordResetEmail(String) again in order to obtain a new password reset token.

        Parameters:
        passwordResetToken - the verification token, usually obtained as a request parameter by your application.
        newPassword - the new password that will be set to the Account if the token is successfully validated.
        Returns:
        the Account matching the specified token.
        Since:
        1.0.RC
        See Also:
        sendPasswordResetEmail(String)

      • authenticateAccount

        AuthenticationResult authenticateAccount(AuthenticationRequest request)
                                  throws ResourceException
        Authenticates an account's submitted principals and credentials (e.g. username and password). The account must be in one of the Application's assigned account stores. If not in an assigned account store, the authentication attempt will fail.

        Example

        Consider the following username/password-based example: 

         AuthenticationRequest request = UsernamePasswordRequest.builder()
                         .setUsernameOrEmail(username)
                         .setPassword(submittedRawPlaintextPassword)
                         .build();
 Account authenticated = appToTest.authenticateAccount(request).getAccount();
        Additionally, the Account can be requested to be expanded to avoid a new network transfer when obtaining it: 

         BasicAuthenticationOptions options = UsernamePasswordRequest.options().withAccount();
 AuthenticationRequest request = UsernamePasswordRequest.builder()
                         .setUsernameOrEmail(username)
                         .setPassword(submittedRawPlaintextPassword)
                         .withResponseOptions(options)
                         .build();
 Account authenticated = appToTest.authenticateAccount(request).getAccount();
        Parameters:
        request - the authentication request representing an account's principals and credentials (e.g. username/password) used to verify their identity.
        Returns:
        the result of the authentication. The authenticated account can be obtained from result.getAccount().
        Throws:
        ResourceException - if the authentication attempt fails.

      • getAccount

        ProviderAccountResult getAccount(ProviderAccountRequest request)
        Retrieves a Provider-based Account. The account must exist in one of the Provider-based Directories assigned to the Application as an account store, the Directory must also be Enabled. If not in an assigned account store, the retrieval attempt will fail.

        Example

        Consider the following example: 

         ProviderAccountRequest request = Providers.GOOGLE.account()
                  .setCode("4/mV9k80PpUB7XK_2RvOqOkNrI7I8C.krFm0WYFM_sY3pEBd8D1tNHT8u6jiwI")
                  .build();
 ProviderAccountResult result = application.getAccount(request);
 Account account = result.getAccount();
        Parameters:
        request - the ProviderAccountRequest representing the Provider-specific account access data (e.g. accessToken) used to verify the identity.
        Returns:
        the result of the access request. The Account can be obtained from result.getAccount().
        Throws:
        ResourceException - if the access attempt fails.
        Since:
        1.0.beta

      • getAccountStoreMappings

        ApplicationAccountStoreMappingList getAccountStoreMappings()
        Returns all ApplicationAccountStoreMappings accessible to the application.

        Tip: Instead of iterating over all accountStoreMappings, it might be more convenient (and practical) to execute a search for one or more accountStoreMappings using the getAccountStoreMappings(java.util.Map) method or the getAccountStoreMappings(ApplicationAccountStoreMappingCriteria) instead of this one.

        Returns:
        all ApplicationAccountStoreMappings accessible to the application.
        Since:
        0.9
        See Also:
        getAccountStoreMappings(java.util.Map), getAccountStoreMappings(ApplicationAccountStoreMappingCriteria)

      • getAccountStoreMappings

        ApplicationAccountStoreMappingList getAccountStoreMappings(Map<String,Object> queryParams)
        Returns a paginated list of the application's mapped Account stores that also match the specified query criteria.

        Each queryParams key/value pair will be converted to String name to String value pairs and appended to the resource URL as query parameters, for example: 

         .../applications/applicationId/accountStoreMappings?param1=value1¶m2=value2&...

        This is a type-unsafe alternative to the getAccountStoreMappings(accountStoreMappingCriteria) method, and might be useful when using dynamic languages like Groovy or JRuby. Users of compiled languages, or those that like IDE-completion, might favor the type-safe method instead.

        Parameters:
        queryParams - the query parameters to use when performing a request to the collection.
        Returns:
        a paginated list of the application's mapped account stores that match the specified query criteria.
        Since:
        0.9
        See Also:
        getAccountStoreMappings(ApplicationAccountStoreMappingCriteria)

      • getAccountStoreMappings

        ApplicationAccountStoreMappingList getAccountStoreMappings(ApplicationAccountStoreMappingCriteria criteria)
        Returns a paginated list of the application's mapped Account stores that also match the specified query criteria. The ApplicationAccountStoreMappings utility class is available to help construct the criteria DSL. For example: 
         application.getAccountStoreMappings(ApplicationAccountStoreMappings.criteria()
     .withAccountStore()
     .orderByListIndex();
        or, if using static imports: 
         import static com.stormpath.sdk.application.ApplicationAccountStoreMappings.*;

 ...

 application.getAccountStoreMappings(criteria()
     .withAccountStore()
     .orderByListIndex();
        Parameters:
        criteria - the criteria to use when performing a request to the collection.
        Returns:
        a paginated list of the application's mapped account stores that match the specified query criteria.
        Since:
        1.0.RC9

      • createAccountStoreMapping

        ApplicationAccountStoreMapping createAccountStoreMapping(ApplicationAccountStoreMapping mapping)
                                                  throws ResourceException
        Creates a new ApplicationAccountStoreMapping for this Application, allowing the associated accountStore to be used as a source of accounts that may login to the Application.

        Usage Notice: Unlike other methods in this class that require the Saveable.save() method to be called to persist changes, this is a convenience method will call the server immediately.

        Authentication Process and ApplicationAccountStoreMapping Order

        During an authentication attempt, an Application consults its mapped account stores in iteration order, trying to find the first matching account to use for authentication. The lower the ApplicationAccountStoreMapping index (closer to zero), the earlier that store is consulted during authentication. If no matching account is found in an account store, the application will move on to the next AccountStore (next highest index) in the list. This continues either a matching account is found, or until all account stores are exhausted. When a matching account is found, the process is short-circuited and the discovered account will be used immediately for authentication.

        When calling this method, you control where the new ApplicationAccountStoreMapping will reside in the Application's overall list by setting its (zero-based) listIndex property before calling this method.

        listIndex values

        • negative: attempting to set a negative listIndex will cause an Error
        • zero: the account store mapping will be the first item in the list (and therefore consulted first during the authentication process).
        • positive: the account store mapping will be inserted at that index. Because list indices are zero-based, the account store will be in the list at position listIndex - 1.
        Any listIndex value equal to or greater than the current list size will automatically append the ApplicationAccountStoreMapping at the end of the list.

        Example

        Setting a new ApplicationAccountStoreMapping's listIndex to 500 and then adding the mapping to an application with an existing 3-item list will automatically save the ApplicationAccountStoreMapping at the end of the list and set its listIndex value to 3 (items at index 0, 1, 2 were the original items, the new fourth item will be at index 3). 
         AccountStore directoryOrGroup = getDirectoryOrGroupYouWantToUseForLogin();
 ApplicationAccountStoreMapping mapping = client.instantiate(ApplicationAccountStoreMapping.class);
 mapping.setAccountStore(directoryOrGroup);
 mapping.setListIndex(3); //this is zero-based, so index 3 == 4th item
 mapping = application.createAccountStoreMapping(mapping);
        Then, when authenticating an account, this AccountStore (directory or group) will be consulted if no others before it in the list found a matching account.

        New Account Storage

        If createAccount(com.stormpath.sdk.account.Account)
        Parameters:
        mapping - the new ApplicationAccountStoreMapping resource to add to the Application's ApplicationAccountStoreMapping list.
        Returns:
        the newly created ApplicationAccountStoreMapping instance.
        Throws:
        ResourceException
        Since:
        0.9

      • addAccountStore

        ApplicationAccountStoreMapping addAccountStore(AccountStore accountStore)
                                        throws ResourceException
        Creates a new ApplicationAccountStoreMapping for this Application and appends that ApplicationAccountStoreMapping to the end of the Application's ApplicationAccountStoreMapping list, allowing the associated accountStore to be used as a source of accounts that may login to the Application.

        Usage Notice: Unlike other methods in this class that require the Saveable.save() method to be called to persist changes, this is a convenience method will call the server immediately.

        Authentication Process and ApplicationAccountStoreMapping Order

        During an authentication attempt, an Application consults its mapped account stores in iteration order, trying to find the first matching account to use for authentication. The lower the ApplicationAccountStoreMapping index (closer to zero), the earlier that store is consulted during authentication. If no matching account is found in an account store, the application will move on to the next AccountStore (next highest index) in the list. This continues either a matching account is found, or until all account stores are exhausted. When a matching account is found, the process is short-circuited and the discovered account will be used immediately for authentication.

        When calling this method, you are setting the new ApplicationAccountStoreMapping to the end of the Application's overall list.

        NOTE: If you already know the account store where the account resides, you can specify it at the time the authentication request is created (for example, UsernamePasswordRequestBuilder.inAccountStore(AccountStore)). This way you will be avoiding the authentication attempt to cycle through the Application's account stores.

        Example

         AccountStore directoryGroupOrOrganization = getDirectoryGroupOrOrganizationYouWantToUseForLogin();
 ApplicationAccountStoreMapping mapping = application.addAccountStore(directoryGroupOrOrganization);
        Then, when authenticating an account, this AccountStore (directory, organization or group) will be consulted if no others before it in the list found a matching account.
        Parameters:
        accountStore - the new AccountStore resource to add to the Application's ApplicationAccountStoreMapping list.
        Returns:
        the newly created ApplicationAccountStoreMapping instance.
        Throws:
        ResourceException
        Since:
        0.9

        IllegalArgumentException - if the id argument is null or empty.

      • getApiKey

        ApiKey getApiKey(String id,
                 ApiKeyOptions options)
          throws ResourceException,
                 IllegalArgumentException
        Gets an ApiKey, by its id, that belongs to an Account that has access to this application by a mapped account store.

        A call to this method ensures that the returned ApiKey response reflects the specified ApiKeyOptions.

        Parameters:
        id - the id of the ApiKey to be retrieved.
        options - the ApiKeyOptions to use to customize the ApiKey resource upon retrieval.
        Returns:
        an ApiKey, by its id, that belongs to an Account that has access to this application by a mapped account store with the specified ApiKeyOptions.
        Throws:
        ResourceException - when the ApiKey does not belong to the Account or the ApiKey does not exist.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the id argument is null or empty, or if the options argument is null..
        Since:
        1.0.RC

      • newIdSiteUrlBuilder

        IdSiteUrlBuilder newIdSiteUrlBuilder()
        Creates a new IdSiteUrlBuilder that allows you to build a URL you can use to redirect your application users to a hosted login/registration/forgot-password site - what Stormpath calls an 'Identity Site' (or 'ID Site' for short) - for performing common user identity functionality. When the user is done (logging in, registering, etc), they will be redirected back to a callbackUri of your choice.

        This method is a complement to the newIdSiteCallbackHandler(Object) method: you use this newIdSiteUrlBuilder method to send the end-user to your ID Site. When the end-user is finished on the ID Site and they are returned to your application, you use the newIdSiteCallbackHandler(Object) method to process the result.

        Example

        Let's assume your application's end-users use a web browser to visit your web application at https://awesomeapp.com. When they login, you want to send them to something like https://my.awesomeapp.com or https://id.awesomeapp.com so you don't have to build all the login, registration, and forgot password screens from scratch.

        When your end-user clicks a 'login' link, you would redirect them to your ID Site. That link click request might be handled as follows:

         public void onLoginLinkClick(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) {

  Application application = client.getResource(myApplicationRestUrl, Application.class);

    //this is the fully qualified URL that your end-user should return to after they are finished at the
    // ID Site.  It is usually a URL in your web application, for example: https://awesomeapp.com/id
    // For security reasons, the callbackUri must equal a registered URI in the Stormpath Administration console
    String callbackUri = "https://awesomeapp.com/id";

    String redirectUrl = application.newIdSiteUrlBuilder().setCallbackUri(callbackUri).build();

    response.setHeader("Cache-Control", "no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate");
    response.addHeader("Cache-Control", "post-check=0, pre-check=0");
    response.setHeader("Pragma", "no-cache");

    //send a 302 redirect to your ID Site.  When they're done, they will return to your callbackUri:
    response.sendRedirect(redirectUrl);
 }

        When the end-user is done using your ID Site, they will be redirected back to your specified callbackUri. Requests submitted to your callbackUri should be handled via the newIdSiteCallbackHandler(Object) method.

        Returns:
        a new IdSiteUrlBuilder that allows you to build a URL you can use to redirect your application users to a hosted login/registration/forgot-password 'ID Site'.
        Since:
        1.0.RC2
        See Also:
        IdSiteUrlBuilder.setCallbackUri(String), IdSiteUrlBuilder.setPath(String), IdSiteUrlBuilder.setState(String)

      • newSamlIdpUrlBuilder

        SamlIdpUrlBuilder newSamlIdpUrlBuilder()
        Creates a new SamlIdpUrlBuilder that allows you to build a URL you can use to redirect your application users to a SAML authentication site (Identity Provider or IdP) for performing common user identity functionality. When users are done (logging in, logging out, etc), they will be redirected back to a callbackUri of your choice.
        Example

        Let's assume your application's end-users use a web browser to visit your web application at https://awesomeapp.com. When they login, you want to send them to something like https://awesomeapp.com/userHome so you don't have to build all the login, registration, and forgot password screens from scratch.

        When your end-user clicks a 'login' link, you would redirect them to your SAML IdP page. That link click request might be handled as follows:

         public void onLoginLinkClick(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) {

  Application application = client.getResource(myApplicationRestUrl, Application.class);

    // This is the fully qualified URL that your end-user should return to after they are finished at the
    // SAML IdP Site.  It is usually a URL in your web application, for example: https://my.awesomeapp.com

    String callbackUri = "https://awesomeapp.com/userHome";
    String redirectUrl = application.newSamlIdpUrlBuilder().SamlIdpUrlBuilder.setCallbackUri(String) setCallbackUri}(callbackUri).build();

    response.setHeader("Cache-control", "no-cache, no-store");
    response.setHeader("Pragma", "no-cache");

    //send a 302 redirect to your SAML IdP.  When they're done, they will return to your callbackUri:
    response.sendRedirect(redirectUrl);
 }

        When the end-user is done using your ID Site, he will be redirected back to your specified callbackUri. Requests submitted to your callbackUri should be handled via the newSamlCallbackHandler(Object) method.

        Returns:
        a new SamlIdpUrlBuilder that allows you to build a URL you can use to redirect your application users to a SAML authentication site (Identity Provider or IdP).
        Since:
        1.0.RC8
        See Also:
        SamlIdpUrlBuilder.setCallbackUri(String)

      • newIdSiteCallbackHandler

        IdSiteCallbackHandler newIdSiteCallbackHandler(Object httpRequest)
        Creates a new IdSiteCallbackHandler used to handle HTTP replies from your ID Site to your application's callbackUri, as described in the newIdSiteUrlBuilder() method.

        This method should be called when processing an HTTP request sent by the ID Site to the callbackUri specified via the newIdSiteUrlBuilder() method.

        Example

        Assume that you previously newIdSiteUrlBuilder(), built the URL, and redirected your end-user to that URL. When the end-user is finished interacting with your ID Site, they will be redirected back to the callbackUri you specified when constructing the URL. You would call this method when processing the request to that callbackUri.

        For example, assume your callbackUri is https://awesomeapp.com/id and you process requests to that URI with a (sample) onIdSiteCallback method below:

         public void onIdSiteCallback(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) {

  Application application = client.getResource(myApplicationRestUrl, Application.class);

    AccountResult result = application.newIdSiteCallbackHandler(request).getAccountResult();

    //get the account that signed-up or logged in successfully:
    Account account = result.getAccount();

    //do whatever you want with the returned account :)

    // result.isNewAccount() == true for a newly registered user
    // result.isNewAccount() == false for an existing user that logged in

    // When you're done, you might want to redirect the end-user to a welcome page or
    // a 'my account' page, for example:
    response.sendRedirect("/myaccount");
 }
        Servlet Container or No Servlet Container?

        This method will accept either a javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest instance if your app is running in a Servlet container, or a manually-constructed HttpRequest instance if it is not. See the HttpRequests helper class to help build the request object if you are running in a non-servlet environment.

        Parameters:
        httpRequest - either an javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest instance (if your app runs in a Servlet container) or a manually-constructed HttpRequest instance if it does not.
        Returns:
        an IdSiteCallbackHandler that allows you customize how the httpRequest will be handled.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the method argument is null or is not either a either a javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest or HttpRequest instance.
        Since:
        1.0.RC2
        See Also:
        newIdSiteUrlBuilder(), HttpRequests, IdSiteCallbackHandler, IdSiteCallbackHandler.getAccountResult()

      • newSamlCallbackHandler

        SamlCallbackHandler newSamlCallbackHandler(Object httpRequest)
        Creates a new SamlCallbackHandler used to handle HTTP replies from your SAML Identity Provider (SAML IdP) to your application's callbackUri, as described in the newSamlIdpUrlBuilder() method.

        This method should be called when processing an HTTP request sent by the SAML IdP to the callbackUri specified via the newSamlIdpUrlBuilder() method.

        Example

        Assume that you previously built the URL using the newSamlIdpUrlBuilder(), and redirected your end-user to that URL. When the end-user is finished interacting with your SAML IdP Site, they will be redirected back to the callbackUri you specified when constructing the URL. You would call this method when processing the request to that callbackUri.

        For example, assume your callbackUri is https://awesomeapp.com/userHome and you process requests to that URI with a (sample) onSamlIdpCallback method below:

         public void onSamlIdpCallback(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) {

  Application application = client.getResource(myApplicationRestUrl, Application.class);

    AccountResult result = application.newSamlCallbackHandler(request).getAccountResult();

    //get the account that signed-up or logged in successfully:
    Account account = result.getAccount();

 }
        Servlet Container or No Servlet Container?

        This method will accept either a javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest instance if your app is running in a Servlet container, or a manually-constructed HttpRequest instance if it is not. See the HttpRequests helper class to help build the request object if you are running in a non-servlet environment.

        Parameters:
        httpRequest - either an javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest instance (if your app runs in a Servlet container) or a manually-constructed HttpRequest instance if it does not.
        Returns:
        an SamlCallbackHandler that allows you customize how the httpRequest will be handled.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the method argument is null or is not either a either a javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest or HttpRequest instance.
        Since:
        1.0.RC8
        See Also:
        newSamlIdpUrlBuilder(), HttpRequests, IdSiteCallbackHandler, IdSiteCallbackHandler.getAccountResult()

      • sendVerificationEmail

        void sendVerificationEmail(VerificationEmailRequest verificationEmailRequest)
        Triggers the delivery of a new verification email for the specified account.

        This method is useful in scenarios where the Account Registration and Verification workflow is enabled. If the welcome email has not been received by a newly registered account, then the user will not be able to login until the account is verified.

        This method re-sends the verification email and allows the user to verify the account.

        The VerificationEmailRequest resource must contain the email or the username identifying the account. If the optional AccountStore is also specified, the desired Account will be sought only in that specific AccountStore. Sample code: 

              Directory dir = client.getResource("https://api.stormpath.com/v1/directories/7WcyHGlDa0V2Nk11Vum3Zd", Directory.class);
      VerificationEmailRequest verificationEmailRequest = Applications.verificationEmailBuilder()
                                          .setLogin("myaccountemail@mycompany.com")
                                          .setAccountStore(dir)
                                          .build();
      application.sendVerificationEmail(verificationEmailRequest);
        Parameters:
        verificationEmailRequest - contains the required information for the verification email to be sent.
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • addAccountStore

        ApplicationAccountStoreMapping addAccountStore(String hrefOrName)
        Convenience method to add a a new AccountStore to this application.

        The given String can be either an 'href' or a 'name' of a Directory or a Group belonging to the current Tenant.

        If the provided value is an 'href', this method will get the proper Resource and add it as a new AccountStore in this Application without much effort. However, if the provided value is not an 'href', it will be considered as a 'name'. In this case, this method will search for both a Directory and a Group whose names equal the provided hrefOrName. If only one resource exists (either a Directory or a Group), then it will be added as a new AccountStore in this Application. However, if there are two resources (a Directory and a Group) matching that name, a ResourceException will be thrown.

        At the end of this process, if a single matching resource is found, this method will then delegate the actual ApplicationAccountStoreMapping creation to the addAccountStore(AccountStore) method in order to fulfill its task.

        Example providing an href: 

              ApplicationAccountStoreMapping accountStoreMapping = application.addAccountStore("https://api.stormpath.com/v1/groups/2rwq022yMt4u2DwKLfzriP");
        Example providing a name: 

              ApplicationAccountStoreMapping accountStoreMapping = application.addAccountStore("Foo Name");
        USAGE NOTE 1: When using 'names' this method is not efficient as it will search for both Directories and Groups within this Tenant for a matching name. In order to do so, some looping takes place at the client side: groups exist within directories, therefore we need to loop through every existing directory in order to find the required Group. In contrast, providing the Group's 'href' is much more efficient as no actual search operation needs to be carried out.

        USAGE NOTE 2: Unlike other methods in this class that require the Saveable.save() method to be called to persist changes, this is a convenience method and will call the server immediately.

        Parameters:
        hrefOrName - either the 'href' or the 'name' of the desired Directory or Group.
        Returns:
        the ApplicationAccountStoreMapping created after finding the actual resource described by hrefOrName. It returns null if there is no group or directory matching the href or name given.
        Throws:
        ResourceException - if the resource already exists as an account store in this application.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the given hrefOrName matches more than one resource in the current Tenant.
        Since:
        1.0.RC3
        See Also:
        addAccountStore(com.stormpath.sdk.directory.DirectoryCriteria), addAccountStore(com.stormpath.sdk.group.GroupCriteria)

      • addAccountStore

        ApplicationAccountStoreMapping addAccountStore(DirectoryCriteria criteria)
        Convenience method to add a new Directory as an AccountStore to this application.

        The provided DirectoryCriteria must match a single Directory in the current Tenant. If more than one Directory matches the criteria, an IllegalArgumentException will be thrown. If no Directory matches the criteria, this method will return null.

        When a single Directory is found, this method will then delegate the actual ApplicationAccountStoreMapping creation to the addAccountStore(AccountStore) method in order to fulfill its task.

        Example: 

              DirectoryCriteria criteria = Directories.criteria().add(Directories.name().eqIgnoreCase("Foo Dir Name"));
      ApplicationAccountStoreMapping accountStoreMapping = application.addAccountStore(criteria);

        USAGE NOTE 1: Unlike other methods in this class that require the Saveable.save() method to be called to persist changes, this is a convenience method and will call the server immediately.

        Parameters:
        criteria - to search for the desired Directory to be added as an AccountStore.
        Returns:
        the ApplicationAccountStoreMapping created after finding the actual resource matching the criteria. It returns null if there is no Directory matching the criteria.
        Throws:
        ResourceException - if the found Directory already exists as an account store in this application.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the criteria matches more than one Group in the current Tenant.
        Since:
        1.0.RC3

      • addAccountStore

        ApplicationAccountStoreMapping addAccountStore(OrganizationCriteria criteria)
        Convenience method to add a new Organization as an AccountStore to this application.

        The provided OrganizationCriteria must match a single Organization in the current Tenant. If more than one Organization matches the criteria, an IllegalArgumentException will be thrown. If no Organization matches the criteria, this method will return null.

        When a single Organization is found, this method will then delegate the actual ApplicationAccountStoreMapping creation to the addAccountStore(AccountStore) method in order to fulfill its task.

        Example: 

              OrganizationCriteria criteria = Organizations.criteria().add(Organizations.name().eqIgnoreCase("Org Name"));
      ApplicationAccountStoreMapping accountStoreMapping = application.addAccountStore(criteria);

        USAGE NOTE 1: Unlike other methods in this class that require the Saveable.save() method to be called to persist changes, this is a convenience method and will call the server immediately.

        Parameters:
        criteria - to search for the desired Organization to be added as an AccountStore.
        Returns:
        the ApplicationAccountStoreMapping created after finding the actual resource matching the criteria. It returns null if there is no Organization matching the criteria.
        Throws:
        ResourceException - if the found Organization already exists as an account store in this application.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the criteria matches more than one Organization in the current Tenant.
        Since:
        1.0.RC7

      • addAccountStore

        ApplicationAccountStoreMapping addAccountStore(GroupCriteria criteria)
        Convenience method to add a new Group as an AccountStore to this application.

        The provided GroupCriteria must match a single Group in the current Tenant. If more than one Group matches the criteria, an IllegalArgumentException will be thrown. If no Group matches the criteria, this method will return null.

        When a single Group is found, this method will then delegate the actual ApplicationAccountStoreMapping creation to the addAccountStore(AccountStore) method in order to fulfill its task.

        Example: 

              GroupCriteria criteria = Groups.criteria().add(Groups.name().containsIgnoreCase("Foo Group Name"));
      ApplicationAccountStoreMapping accountStoreMapping = application.addAccountStore(criteria);

        USAGE NOTE 1: This method is not efficient as it will search for every Group within every Directory of this Tenant. In order to do so, some looping takes place at the client side: groups exist within directories, therefore we need to loop through every existing directory in order to find the required group. In contrast, if the Group's 'href' is already known, we suggest using addAccountStore(String) with the Group's 'href' since it is a more efficient mechanism where no actual search needs to be carried out.

        USAGE NOTE 2: Unlike other methods in this class that require the Saveable.save() method to be called to persist changes, this is a convenience method and will call the server immediately.

        Parameters:
        criteria - to search for the desired Group to be added as an AccountStore.
        Returns:
        the ApplicationAccountStoreMapping created after finding the actual resource matching the criteria. It returns null if there is no Group matching the criteria.
        Throws:
        ResourceException - if the found Group already exists as an account store in this application.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the criteria matches more than one Group in the current Tenant.
        Since:
        1.0.RC3
        See Also:
        addAccountStore(String)

      • saveWithResponseOptions

        Application saveWithResponseOptions(ApplicationOptions responseOptions)
        Saves this Application resource and ensures the returned Application response reflects the specified options. This enhances performance by 'piggybacking' the response to return related resources you know you will use after saving the application.
        Parameters:
        responseOptions - The ApplicationOptions to use to customize the Application resource returned in the save response.
        Returns:
        this instance for method chaining.
        Since:
        1.0.RC4.6
